repnme.cdata!: Hungary - Public Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability. Lessons suggest
            that: 1) implementation of the pension system reform, has
            proved extremely popular among the working population,
            attracting a much larger number of workers than previously
            thought. The voluntary decision to switch to the new
            multi-pillar pension system - comprising a public
            Pay-as-you-go (PAYG) system, and a funded, and
            privately-managed system - was motivated by several factors,
            largely because of higher returns expectations, and the
            perception of political risk in the public system. However,
            overselling of the new system seems to have occurred, making
            older workers switch, when actually they would be better-off
            staying in the reformed PAYG; 2) the changes introduced by
            the new Government to the original design, which reflected
            different policy objectives, such as the cost to employers
            of social security contributions, and concerns about the
            impact of reforms on public finances, caused the Government
            not to proceed as prescribed by law in 1997. Unless such
            increases are effected in the short run, serious
            implications for both members, and market participants could
            arise; and, 3) in the area of disability pensions, the
            program has been unsatisfactory, since none of the reforms
            were incorporated, nor implemented. Restoring contribution
            rates, and strengthening pension funds' regulatory, and
            supervisory framework should be achieved.
